comments.message:
Patch Set 1:

Does this only apply to a certain type of power supply?

A number of the commands/registers are unfamiliar to me.

Patch Set 1:

(14 comments)

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> Does this only apply to a certain type of power supply?
> 
> A number of the commands/registers are unfamiliar to me.

Yes, only to Intel PSU.

Patch Set 2:

(8 comments)

There are quite a few odd rendering issues with this file, making it hard to read after GitHub renders it into a web page.

I Pointed out at least one sentence that was hard to grasp what was being stated.

I would second the Grammarly recommendation.

Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

(6 comments)

I have some comments, but overall it looks in decent shape.

A general suggestion suggested by Gunnar:
copy the text to Grammarly or use Grammarly plugin to fix common spelling and grammar issues.
Update to the day this was pushed?
It could be better to use bullets to indicates each requirement.
Is it to say you will add such properties to the settings daemon?
entity-manager only keep the PSU bus and address of power supplies. If any other D-Bus interfaces can provide this information, it can also work.
set, if I understand it correctly.

It is weird to see the value here.
Maybe you could introduce the RotationAlgorithm first, the value is implementation details and there is no need to indicate here.
Again, I would suggest introducing the settings before the usage here.
What does this mean? Why is it not 86400?
Time format is defined in Redfish schema.

Is it better to name it like NumberOfPSUs.

The name makes me feel like it is an assigned number of a specific PSU, e.g. PSU0, PSU1, etc.

This seems not clear on how it is implemented, it only mentions that this daemon needs to be stopped.

But it needs more clear information on 1) when and how the daemon is stopped; 2) when and how the daemon is re-started.
What if the PSU's rank order was set to 2?
AC lost will reset cold redundancy algo, so even the ranking order on PSU is 2, it will be reset to 1.
Is this intended to be on giant paragraph, or is there some intended separation? This renders on Github.com as one long winded paragraph.
These run on together. I think you need a blank line between them.
This is unreadable when markdown is rendered on github. Need some backticks ``` here?
Is this the same as user-specific up on line 59?
Yes, but here is the Redfish value, line 59 and 110 are D-Bus property value.
Does case matter here? This does not match line 91.
Line 91 is redfish value, here is D-Bus property.

RotationRankOrder is an array which a user may want to set in order to specify the specific RotationAlgorithm.
???
Something with the wording just seems off to me.

According to the configuration parameters received from the settings daemon, ....
?
Depending on the configuration parameters received from the settings daemon, ....
?
Something with how this renders from md to HTML still does not look right. Is this another case of perhaps using ```?

... this daemon would need to be stopped in order to avoid reading and writing PSU registers, so that it does not impact the PSU firmware update.
???

PeriodOfRotation is not allowed to be lower than 1 day
?
Lots of trailing spaces. It is not clear if those were some attempt at getting the rendered document to flow right, or just some inadvertent whitespace additions.
those two spaces at the end of the lines can help markdown feed new lines.
To support the Power Supply Cold Redundancy feature....

only the power supplies needed to support the best power delivery efficiency are ON.
???

...write a PSU register....
...write to PSU registers...
???
...in the settings daemon, the Cold Redundancy service ....

... the Cold Redundancy service will recognize that, and then the service will reload the parameters from the settings daemon.

???

Not sure if this is the problem, but everything from here down, if put into a github.com gist, renders horribly bad.

Does it need ```, new line, text, new line, ```?
```
/xyz/openbmc_project/Control:  
    - Interface: xyz.openbmc_project.Control.PowerSupplyRedundancy  
      Properties:  
        NumberOfPSUs: byte
```
Better to describe this as something like you are going to add some D-Bus properties to the settings service, otherwise, it reads as there are existing D-Bus properties.
I do not think this is valid markdown format, probably you would use a single ` here?

Which service is responsible to do this?
* If it is PSU firmware update daemon, then it needs extra logic to stop the PSU Cold Redundancy service;
* If it is PSU Cold Redundancy service, e.g. it could listen to the PSU software object's properties, it could stop itself as well.

I would prefer the latter, so it does not impact other services. But I am also OK if the former one is done in the vendor-specific tools.

PSU firmware update daemon will need to stop the PSU Cold Redundancy service. We will
define how and when to stop in PSU firmware update design in future, so currently, we
just put this in impacts to remind users about this.
There are quite a few other places that are having tailing spaces as well, remove them all.

They are changed to `
`, please remove them...

In markdown, I know there are two ways to feed line, one is adding two blanks at the end, the other is using
. Do you know any other better method to feed lines?
OK, if you really need line break here, I am OK with this.

Sorry for additional questions:
1. What is PSU manager here?
2. This describes the situation, but it does not provide the solution. So how do you prepare to handle this case?
Oh, sorry, this is not for cold redundancy, I will discuss this later in another topic. I have deleted it from this doc. Thank you very much!
Is this part of the SMBus/PMBus specification? If so could you link to it? If not, can you talk about why this register is expected to be present/defined?
It's in OEM PSU specification, I have changed it.
What's the unit of this property? Minutes? Hours? Days?
Put this in a code block (triple-backticks (`)) and that way we can avoid explicit HTML tags.
See comment above. Fix the rest as well.
This section should also provide an analysis of the trade-offs of each approach and explain why the proposed approach was chosen.

Some testing is described below but it's not clear whether it's intended that these steps be automated or not. Please outline whether they are to be manually executed, or if they are automated, outline your plan for how that's going to be implemented (e.g. using openbmc-test-automation).

Also talk about whether these tests must be executed on hardware, and whether there are any avenues for doing virtualised integration testing (e.g. under QEMU).

Please also set an expectation on unit tests - i.e. that they will be written, and talk about any traps we might need to look out for in doing so.

Have we tried to upstream this to the DMTF ?

Before adding a Redfish OEM schema or property first engage the DMTF's Redfish working group to see if they are interested in adding the new feature.

https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/40d68ef6ebe088e4cd0078f8ff4910ca58f2be5d/DEVELOPING.md
I am working on it. I have a contact in Intel to help add this to Redfish schema, but he is on vacation, so it still needs some time to finish it.
